Rome may belong to the foundation of the first (palatine) city or to the fusion of Romans and Sabines. The word curia (see note on c. ¹3· 6) came to mean both a meeting-place for cere- monial purposes¹ and a district or corporation: and though members of the same curia may in general have dwelt in the ” same quarter, it seems that these associations of families, for such they were, like the φρατρίαι in Greece, originated rather in mutual protection and common worship than in any con- nection of residence. When a larger unit, the state, undertook the duty of protection, the curiae contributed each its quota (centuria) for the levy (legio) ε and similarly, while the special rites of each curia in honour of Iuno &cirins (which seem to suggest a Sabine origin) continued, the whole people celebrated together, according to their curiae, certain other rites (eg. the Fornacalia and the Fordicidia). The curiae were, in, fact, the formal units of the state until the reorganisation of Servius Tullius· To be enrolled in a curia was the warrant of citizen- ship3 and the formalities of adoption (adrogatio) and of testament could only be performed before the assembled curias—the comitia curiata.
